DataElement.preferredName: Breast Carcinoma Disease or Disorder Assessment Anatomic Site Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the location of the breast cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla._Named locations of or within the body.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Property.preferredDefinition: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Named locations of or within the body.

Property.changeDescription: Updated to point to NCI Thesaurus concept code.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: .Updated def for "breast carcinoma". No version needed. AK 9/19/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Disease or Disorder Assessment Anatomic Site Name
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._Named locations of or within the body._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body.

Concepts.definition: The part of the brain that controls muscle functions and also controls speech, thought, emotions, reading, writing, and learning. The right hemisphere controls the muscles on the left side of the body, and the left hemisphere controls the muscles on the right side of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The part of the brain that is connected to the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: Three sections, the midbrain, pons and medulla oblongata, that are located at the base of the brain. The brain stem regulates the central nervous system, and is vital as a conduit for motor and sensory innervations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (mee-dee-a-STYE-num) The area between the lungs. The organs in this area include the heart and its large blood vessels, the trachea, the esophagus, the bronchi, and lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: An anatomic site along the midline and under the sternum that contains the heart and pericardium, the bases of the great vessels, the trachea and bronchi, esophagus, thymus, lymph nodes, thoracic duct, phrenic and vagus nerves, and other structures and tissues.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cranial; of or relating to the cranium.: Any of the bundles of nerve fibers running to various organs and tissues of the body using chemical and electrical signals to transmit sensory and motor information from one body part to another.

Concepts.definition: Of or relating to the cranium.

Part of the peripheral nervous system composed of bundles of nerve fibers running to various organs and tissues of the body using chemical and electrical signals to transmit sensory and motor information from one body part to another.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that flows in and around the hollow spaces of the brain and spinal cord, and between two of the meninges (the thin layers of tissue that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord). CSF is made by tissue called the choroid plexus in the ventricles (hollow spaces) in the brain.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (sair-uh-BELL-um) The portion of the brain in the back of the head between the cerebrum and the brain stem. The cerebellum controls balance for walking and standing, and other complex motor functions.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the brain located at the base of the skull that is responsible for balance, equilibrium and movement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The soft, sponge-like tissue in the center of bones that produces white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.

Concepts.definition: The tissue occupying the spaces of bone. It consists of blood vessel sinuses and a network of hematopoietic cells which give rise to the red cells, white cells, and megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

Concepts.definition: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated concept definition with current NCIt. 4.5.18 mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paired glands situated in the retroperitoneal tissues at the superior pole of each kidney.

Concepts.definition: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

Concepts.definition: The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: 1. An organ and the enveloping membrane of the body; includes, in addition to the epidermis and dermis, all of the derivatives of the epidermis, e.g., hairs, nails, sudoriferous and sebaceous glands, and mammary glands. Subdivisions of the skin surround various body parts; as a whole, the skin constitutes the external surface of the body. 2. The rind, capsule, or covering of any body or part.

Concepts.definition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (PLOOR-a) A thin layer of tissue covering the lungs and the wall of the chest cavity to protect and cushion the lungs. A small amount of fluid that acts as a lubricant allows the lungs to move smoothly in the chest cavity during breathing.

Concepts.definition: The tissue that lines the wall of the thoracic cavity and the surface of the lungs.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lymph nodes found in the armpit that drain the lymph channels from the breast.

Concepts.definition: Lymph nodes found in the armpit that drain the lymph channels from the breast.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has but two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border. SYN pulmo.

Concepts.definition: One of a pair of viscera occupying the pulmonary cavities of the thorax, the organs of respiration in which aeration of the blood takes place. As a rule, the right lung is slightly larger than the left and is divided into three lobes (an upper, a middle, and a lower or basal), while the left has two lobes (an upper and a lower or basal). Each lung is irregularly conical in shape, presenting a blunt upper extremity (the apex), a concave base following the curve of the diaphragm, an outer convex surface (costal surface), an inner or mediastinal surface (mediastinal surface), a thin and sharp anterior border, and a thick and rounded posterior border.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A large organ located in the upper abdomen. The liver cleanses the blood and aids in digestion by secreting bile.

Concepts.definition: A triangular-shaped organ located under the diaphragm in the right hypochondrium. It is the largest internal organ of the body, weighting up to 2 kg. Metabolism and bile secretion are its main functions. It is composed of cells which have the ability to regenerate.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.7 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002119. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

Concepts.definition: The total system of structures outside the lungs that move as a part of breathing; it includes all structures from the skin to the parietal pleura.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Bone; a rigid connective tissue that makes up the skeleton of vertebrates.: Having to do with symptoms, which are signs of a condition or disease.

Concepts.definition: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.
Exhibiting the symptoms of a particular disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Bone; a rigid connective tissue that makes up the skeleton of vertebrates.: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

Concepts.definition: The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.
A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Tumor Marker (p53,CD's Ki, CEA, Her2/Neu, etc.)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Tumor Marker (p53,CD's Ki, CEA, Her2/Neu, etc.)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A substance sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood, other body fluids, or tissues and which may mean that a certain type of cancer is in the body. Examples of tumor markers include CA 125 (ovarian cancer), CA 15-3 (breast cancer), CEA (ovarian, lung, breast, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract cancers), and PSA (prostate cancer). Also called biomarker.

Concepts.definition: A substance present in or produced by a tumor or by the host, that can be used for differentiating neoplastic from normal tissue based on measurements in body fluids, secretions, cells, and/or tissues. Markers are used in diagnosis, staging and prognosis of cancer, provide an estimation of tumor burden, and serve for monitoring effects of therapy, detecting recurrence, localization of tumors, and screening in general populations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Local-Regional; affecting only a restricted part or area of the body.: A rounded mass of lymphatic tissue that is surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue. Lymph glands filter lymph (lymphatic fluid), and they store lymphocytes (white blood cells). They are located along lymphatic vessels. Also called a lymph node.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to both a local and regional area of the body.

A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

Concepts.definition: The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary): Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic pathologic process affecting the leptomeninges of the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic pathologic process affecting the leptomeninges of the spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic pathologic process affecting the leptomeninges of the brain.

Concepts.definition: A non-neoplastic or neoplastic pathologic process affecting the leptomeninges of the brain.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The presence of brain metastasis that originates from a cancer growth in a distant anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: The presence of brain metastasis that originates from a cancer growth in a distant anatomic site.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Situated or occurring outside the nerve or nerves.

Concepts.definition: Situated or occurring outside the nerve or nerves.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.|On-line Medical Dictionary

Concepts.definition: The elongated, approximately cylindrical part of the central nervous system of vertebrates that lies in the vertebral canal and from which the spinal nerves emerge.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Far apart in space from a point of origin on the body.: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Concepts.definition: Far apart in space from a point of origin on the body.

A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Right; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the east when facing north.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Left; being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or relating to the opposite side (of the body): Any of the lymph nodes of the breast located under the ribcage, near the sternum.

Concepts.definition: On or relating to the opposite side of the body.
Any of the lymph nodes of the breast located under the ribcage, near the sternum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node located in the mediastinum. Mediastinal lymph nodes are arranged in three groups, one on the lateral, another on the medial, and a third on the anterior aspect of the vessels; the third group is, however, sometimes absent.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located in the mediastinum. Mediastinal lymph nodes are arranged in three groups, one on the lateral, another on the medial, and a third on the anterior aspect of the vessels; the third group is, however, sometimes absent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node located in the area below the clavicle.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node located in the area below the clavicle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lymph nodes located above the clavicle (collarbone).

Concepts.definition: A lymph node which is located above the clavicle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

Concepts.definition: Either of the paired male reproductive glands that produce the male germ cells and the male hormones.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Cytogenetics And/Or Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Laboratory Test Result

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Cytogenetics And/Or Fluorescence in situ Hybridization Laboratory Test Result
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cytogenetics is the study of chromosomes and the related disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: A type of IN SITU HYBRIDIZATION in which target sequences are stained with fluorescent dye so their location and size can be determined using fluorescence microscopy. This staining is sufficiently distinct that the hybridization signal can be seen both in metaphase spreads and in interphase nuclei.: The outcome of a laboratory test.

Concepts.definition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping.
The outcome of a laboratory test.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Molecular; relating to or produced by or consisting of molecules.: The outcome of a laboratory test.

Concepts.definition: Relating to or produced by or consisting of molecules.
The outcome of a laboratory test.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Elevated; raised or increased.: A group of sympathetic amines containing a catechol group derived from the amino acid tyrosine.  Catecholamines are neuromodulators and hormones synthesized in the chromaffin cells of the adrenal grands and the postganglionic fibers of the sympathetic nervous system in response to stress.  Examples of catecholamines are epinephrine (adrenaline), norepinephrine (noradrenaline) and dopamine, all of which participate in wide variety of functions throughout the body.

Concepts.definition: Raised or increased above normal levels or limits.

A group of sympathetic amines containing a catechol group derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Catecholamines are hormones and neuromodulators synthesized in the chromaffin cells of the adrenal glands and the postganglionic fibers of the sympathetic nervous system in response to stress. Examples of catecholamines are epinephrine (adrenaline), norepinephrine (noradrenaline) and dopamine, all of which participate in a wide variety of functions throughout the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The lower part of the gastrointestinal tract that includes the jejunum and ileum of the small intestine and the large intestine.

Concepts.definition: The lower part of the gastrointestinal tract that includes the jejunum and ileum of the small intestine and the large intestine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The upper part of the gastrointestinal tract that includes the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.

Concepts.definition: The upper part of the gastrointestinal tract that includes the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any disease of the joints.

Concepts.definition: Any disorder of the joints.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The muscular organ located in the floor of the mouth and serving as the principal organ of taste and modification of the voice in speech.

Concepts.definition: The muscular organ located in the floor of the mouth and serving as the principal organ of taste and modification of the voice in speech.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Refers to muscle, fat, fibrous tissue, blood vessels, or other supporting tissue of the body.

Concepts.definition: A general term comprising tissue that is not hardened or calcified; including muscle, fat, blood vessels, nerves, tendons, ligaments and fascia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: That part of the central nervous system contained within the cranium, comprising the prosencephalon, mesencephalon, and rhombencephalon. It is derived from the anterior part of the embryonic neural tube. Functions include muscle control and coordination, sensory reception and integration, speech production, memory storage, and the elaboration of thought and emotions.

Concepts.definition: An organ composed of grey and white matter containing billions of neurons that is the center for intelligence and reasoning. It is protected by the bony cranium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (sair-uh-BELL-um) The portion of the brain in the back of the head between the cerebrum and the brain stem. The cerebellum controls balance for walking and standing, and other complex motor functions.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: A medial narrow structure connecting the two hemispheres of the cerebellum.

Concepts.definition: The portion of the brain located at the base of the skull that is responsible for balance, equilibrium and movement.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
A medial narrow structure connecting the two hemispheres of the cerebellum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Hypothalamus is an important supervisory center in the brain, rich in ganglia, nerve fibers, and synaptic connections. It is composed of several sections called nuclei, each of which controls a specific function. The hypothalamus regulates body temperatur: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: The region above or over the sella turcica.

Concepts.definition: An important supervisory center in the brain, rich in ganglia, nerve fibers, and synaptic connections. It is composed of several sections called nuclei, each of which controls a specific function. The hypothalamus regulates body temperature, blood pressure, heartbeat, metabolism of fats and carbohydrates, and sugar levels in the blood. Through direct attachment to the pituitary gland, the hypothalamus also meters secretions controlling water balance and milk production in the female. The role of the hypothalamus in awareness of pleasure and pain is well established in the laboratory. It is involved in the expression of emotions, such as fear and rage, and in sexual behaviors. Despite its numerous vital functions, the hypothalamus in humans accounts for only 1/300 of total brain weight, and is about the size of an almond. Structurally, it is joined to the thalamus; the two work together to monitor the sleep-wake cycle.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
The area above or over the sella turcica.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: A rounded mass of lymphatic tissue that is surrounded by a capsule of connective tissue. Lymph glands filter lymph (lymphatic fluid), and they store lymphocytes (white blood cells). They are located along lymphatic vessels. Also called a lymph node.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Thalamus And/Or Basal Ganglia And/Or Corpus Callosum

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Thalamus And/Or Basal Ganglia And/Or Corpus Callosum
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (THAL-a-muss) An area of the brain that helps process information from the senses and transmit it to other parts of the brain.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: subcortical masses of gray matter of the cerebrum, namely, the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, amygdala, and clastrum; involved in initiating and directing voluntary movements.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: the main neocortical commissure of the cerebral hemispheres; it is subdivided into a genu, a rostrum, a body, and a splenium.

Concepts.definition: An ovoid mass composed predominantly of gray substance and associated laminae of white substance. The thalamus is divided into anterior, medial, and lateral parts. The function of the thalamus is to relay sensory impulses and cerebellar and basal ganglia projections to the cerebral cortex. The thalamus is positioned within the posterior part of the diencephalon forming most of each lateral wall of the third ventricle.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

Clusters of neurons comprising the globus pallidus, putamen, caudate, nucleus accumbens, substantia nigra and subthalamic nucleus. They are involved with high level aspects of inhibitory motor activity in coordination with the excitation commands issued from the cerebellum.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
A white matter structure within the cleft that separates the left and right cerebral hemispheres in the mammalian brain. It is composed of a wide, flat bundle of 200-250 million axonal projections.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Affecting both sides of the body, or a matched pair of organs.: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.: Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options: Beneath the skin.

Concepts.definition: An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
Beneath the skin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

Concepts.definition: A bean-shaped organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is part of the lymphatic system and is found throughout the body. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and its main function is immune protection.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sympathetic ganglion located adjacent to the spinal column.

Concepts.definition: A sympathetic ganglion located adjacent to the spinal column.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The area of the body behind the orbit of the eye.

Concepts.definition: The area of the body behind the orbit of the eye.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: External Central Nervous System Primary Anatomic Site

ValueMeaning.preferredName: External Central Nervous System Primary Anatomic Site
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.: The main information-processing organs of the nervous system, consisting of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.: Occurring first in time or sequence; original. (American Heritage Dictionary): Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Happening or arising or located outside or beyond some limits, or especially, some surface.
The part of the nervous system that consists of the brain, spinal cord, and meninges.
Occurring first in time or sequence; original; of greatest rank or importance or value.
Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secret the metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining the homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

Concepts.definition: One of the two bean-shaped organs located on each side of the spine in the retroperitoneum. The right kidney is located below the liver and the left kidney below the diaphragm. The kidneys filter and secrete metabolic products and minerals from the blood, thus maintaining homeostasis. On the superior pole of each kidney there is an adrenal gland. Each kidney and adrenal gland is surrounded by fat.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood circulating throughout the body.

Concepts.definition: A liquid tissue; its major function is to transport oxygen throughout the body. It also supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection. Several hormones also travel in the blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organ that is part of the lymphatic system. The spleen produces lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells. It is located on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach.

Concepts.definition: An organ that is part of the hematopoietic and immune systems. It is composed of the white pulp and the red pulp and is surrounded by a capsule. It is located in the left hypochondriac region. Its functions include lymphocyte production, blood cell storage, and blood cell destruction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

Concepts.definition: The upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract is comprised of mouth, pharynx, esophagus and stomach while the lower GI tract consists of intestines and anus. The primary function of the GI tract is to ingest, digest, absorb and ultimately excrete food stuff.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Space between the dura mater and the walls of the vertebral canal.

Concepts.definition: Space between the dura mater and the walls of the vertebral canal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Named locations of, or within, the body.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Named locations of or within the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Affecting the entire body.

Concepts.definition: Affecting an entire system.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.: A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of bone.

Concepts.definition: A pathological hardening or thickening of tissue, especially that of the interstitial substance.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of bone.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A plasma cell neoplasm arising at an extraosseous site. There is no involvement of the bone marrow. It most frequently involves the oropharynx, nasopharynx, sinuses, and larynx. Other sites of involvement include the gastrointestinal tract, central nervous system, breast, skin, lymph nodes, and bladder.  A minority of patients have a monoclonal gammopathy. Treatment includes radiation therapy. Progression to plasma cell myeloma occurs in a minority of patients.

Concepts.definition: A localized malignant neoplasm arising in an extraosseous site. It is composed of clonal (malignant) plasma cells forming a tumor mass. It most frequently involves the oropharynx, nasopharynx, sinuses, and larynx.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Destruction of an area of bone due to a disease process, such as cancer.

Concepts.definition: Destruction of an area of bone due to a disease process, such as cancer.

PermissibleValues.value: Abdominal Renal Fossa (prior operative tumor bed)
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Prior Operative Tumor Bed Abdominal Renal Fossa

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Prior Operative Tumor Bed Abdominal Renal Fossa
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.: Occurring during or associated with a surgical procedure.: The tissue that envelopes a tumor site, following the surgical removal of the tumor.: Of, or related to, the abdomen.: The usual retroperitoneal location of the kidney in the dorsolumbar region of the body.

Concepts.definition: Earlier in time or order.
Occurring during or associated with a surgical procedure.
The tissue that envelopes a tumor site, following the surgical removal of the tumor.
Of, or related to, the abdomen.
The usual retroperitoneal location of the kidney in the dorsolumbar region of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A lymph node outside the abdominal cavity.

Concepts.definition: A lymph node outside the abdominal cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any lymph node within the abdomen.

Concepts.definition: Any lymph node within the abdomen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Deposits of borderline, malignant, and rarely benign tumors, usually from the ovary, on the peritoneal surface.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ball-and-socket joint at the upper end of the humerus, located at the junction of humerus and scapula.

Concepts.definition: A ball-and-socket joint at the upper end of the humerus, located at the junction of humerus and scapula.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

Concepts.definition: A joint connecting the lower part of the femur with the upper part of the tibia. The lower part of the femur and the upper part of the tibia are attached to each other by ligaments. Other structures of the knee joint include the upper part of the fibula, located below and parallel to the tibia, and the patella which moves as the knee bends.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ball-and-socket joint between the head of the femur and the acetabulum.

Concepts.definition: A ball-and-socket joint between the head of the femur and the acetabulum.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.:Named locations of, or within, the body.:The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person.
